At the call yesterday I talked about how there were many BFTs, each with different advantages and limitations. A partial list:
I’m not sure which a variant specifically OBC is using.

To an important point of last meeting, here is a academic paper that simulated a large number of BFTs, and reports "one-size-fits-all protocols may be hard if not impossible to design in practice.” <https://www.mpi-sws.org/~druschel/publications/BFTSim-nsdi08.pdf>

text:
<@U0UFDAS91>: OBC uses PBFT, as described by Castro&Liskov (he is at Microsoft only now). My cited paper is a pedagogical introduction to Paxos and PBFT, not a new protocol itself. 
The "Sieve" protocol in OBC  is described in here --  <http://arxiv.org/abs/1603.07351>

yes, there are many more, and consensus protocols for blockchain are an active topic of research. we plan to bring together many researchers in this domain at the 1-day workshop in July in Chicago (<http://www.zurich.ibm.com/dccl/>)

I’m hoping that we can have more and better simulations so we can have better evaluations for which is best under what conditions. I hear claims that stellar can do >100 members of federation, for instance. RBFT also claims larger federations but faster than stellar. Hard to evaluate today.
Then there are the non-BFTs, like PoW, PoS,  PoS+PoW, PoET, PoB, etc.

Indeed, but this is a matter of current research. There are dozens of protocols in the literature related to PBFT (concurrent or follow-ups).

Very recently there have been research proposals for scalable quorum-based protocols for Bitcoin-like systems, like:
-Honey Badger  ( <https://eprint.iacr.org/2016/199> )
-Bitcoin Meets Strong Consistency  ( <http://www.tik.ee.ethz.ch/file/ed3e5da74fbca5584920e434d9976a12/peercensus.pdf>)
-SCP ( <https://eprint.iacr.org/2015/1168> )
None of them have been widely verified and understood (as is PBFT).
Folks, the Arch-WG will have a session Friday 5/6 9:30 AM ET. We have webex  dial-in for those who can't make it in-person.

Dial-In for the Arch-WG session at the F2F 9:30 AM ET.

Main agenda topic is continuing is the discussion on Consensus module interface and and functional definition.

text: Is there recording of this meeting?  I have a standing conflict every Wed. 9-10am.  Please record.  Thank you.
Here are my notes from working sessions on Consensus and Smart-Contract layers functional specification and interaction with <@U0KPYF3PF> <@U0MT4CBHB> <@U0KN2SSKE> and Marko V. from IBM fabric team:

Smart-Contract/Validation and Consensus functions description modeled after bitcoin blockchain and Sawtooth lake:

1. Receives transaction (tx) from communication layer (unicast from client-node)
2. Validates tx – executes the validation/business-logic and stores result in scratch space, if tx is valid. If invalid tx is tossed
3. Transmits tx to network (broadcast to peers) via communication layer
4. Block-creator: creates blocks and validates – by executing tx in-order (check for inconsistencies/double-spends within block, and tosses any invalid txs). Block could contain the hash of global-state.
5. Sends validated block to Consensus module
6. Block-Validator: Receives transaction from Consensus module and executes tx -in–order and validates block, sends response to Consensus.
Consensus module:
1. Block-creator: Receives validated block from SC function and starts consensus protocol to peer-nodes (broadcast) via communication layer.
2. Block-validator: Receives proposed-block from peer via communication layer, and send to SC function for block-validation – Uses response in Consensus process (e.g. Votes Yes if block is valid)
3. Output of Consensus is agreement on ordered set of valid tx. If Block contains hash of global-state, also verifies global state is consistent. If Consensus is not reached tx returned to “mempool”?
What are failure modes and how do we recover?

IBM fabric proposal to handle confidential transactions: 2-phase approach with endorsing peers  who endorse (pre-validate) tx that are received from submitting peer. Endorsers have clear-text access and can execute and validate tx. A submitting peer which receives sufficient number of endorsements to meet the endorsement policy will include tx in 2nd phase block-generation at consensus services. The consensus service does not have clear-text access to tx data, and hence cannot validate tx – it only creates an ordered list of tx for inclusion in a block. (Need a second pass validation to eliminate double-spend tx’s within a proposed block). This proposal will be described shortly in fabric docs in the wiki.
Unfortunately I have a last minute conflict and will not be able to join tomorrow 9 AM PT call. <@U0KPYF3PF> has kindly volunteered to lead the meeting tomorrow.

Proposed Agenda: 1) Recap of working session discussions 2) Requirement for confidential transaction 3) Continue discussion on Consensus and Smart-Contract modules functional decomposition and interface definition.

text: Folks, in case you have not joined the mail-list yet, please do so. I sent this to the mail-list yesterday:

Folks,

I’ve taken a stab at generalizing the first approach, that we’ve been discussing in the arch-wg, to include the concept of a “validating set”. Wanted to address the requirement where only a subset of peers (similar to endorsers) execute a transaction, and adopting the state-update concept.

The aim is to see if the simpler approach has legs. 

Validating-set: Set of validating peer nodes that have cleartext access and authorization to execute and validate transactions
Validation-policy: Rules on what constitutes a valid-tx (similar to endorsement policy)

Smart Contract Function:
Receives tx from communication layer (unicast from client-node)
If this peer is part of validating-set, executes the validation/business-logic and stores result in scratch-space, if tx is valid. Computes state-update, and optionally includes it in tx sent to network. (In this model, it seems we may not need version-dependencies). Tx is rejected/tossed if not-valid.
Transmit tx to network (broadcast to peers) via communication layer
Block-creator (leader) role: Creates proposed block – ordered list of “valid" tx. Uses state-update information to eliminate potentially conflicting txs (e.g. Double spend txs would be updating using same key.). Sends block to Consensus layer.
Block-validator role: Executes each tx in received block that it is authorized to (I.e. This peer belongs to validating set of tx) and appends it’s “validation(endorsement)” to each valid tx. Checks state-update info for inconsistencies for other txs, that it can not execute. Sends validation responses to Consensus layer.
Block-committer: Commits all state-updates on completion of consensus
Consensus Function:
Block-creator (leader) role: Receives proposed block from SC function and starts consensus protocol to peer-nodes (broadcast) via communication layer. Ensures validation-policy is enforced. 
Block-validator role: Receives proposed-block from peer via communication layer, and send to SC function for block-validation – Uses response in Consensus process and confirms that validation-policy is enforced (Additional round of communication may be needed for confirmation.)
Output of Consensus is agreement on ordered set of valid tx. If Block contains hash of global-state, also verifies global state is consistent. If Consensus is not reached tx returned to “mempool”?
Please review and lets discuss by e-mail and on the arch-WG call on Wednesday.
Webex link for meeting at 9 AM call: <https://cisco.webex.com/ciscosales/e.php?MTID=m4c8de547c4824438a65ea23144baea68>

<@U0KM3Q4FL|stan.liberman> uploaded a file: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/stan.liberman/F1VCK7A2Z/sancus-paper-short.pdf|sancus-paper-short.pdf> and commented: I’ve been finally able to get legal approval to circulate a whitepaper draft describing an abstraction and generalization model for distributed ledgers. It was written a number of months ago, but due to corporate controls I’ve not been able to send it out and actually had to cut it up a little. I think it still explains the idea sufficiently to reason about it. I feel it’s relevant to the conversations we’re having in the Architecture WG.

text: Hi guys, in hypberledger, I understood we should not store big file into the ledger or state, and should keep it outside. We should just keep the signature (hash) of such big file
After quick Google, I found that in Ethereum world, there are some storage service such as Ethereum Swarm / IPFS
anything similar in hyperledger?... how should we architect such requirements?
as the file is supposed to be accessed by all VPs/NVPs... should we just architect the file storage as a secured file storage?

<@U1JAPLQSY> thats a good question. It seems that a file storage service could be a useful component, and its a good topic to discuss. We could go down the path of incorporating a particular file system, or we could incorporate an abstraction layer, and let implementations/deployments choose their favorite file-system. Thoughts?
Folks, please indicate your availability for the Arch-WG Documentation working sessions next week here: <http://doodle.com/poll/5b5xevviwu2af68a>

Discussed today : Right to be forgotten - does Recital 65 mean that for financial services with record-retention policies of e.g. Customer Relationship + 7 years, the following get-out may remove the right? "However, the further retention of the personal data should be lawful where it is necessary, for exercising the right of freedom of expression and information, for compliance with a legal obligation, for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller, on the grounds of public interest in the area of public health, for archiving purposes in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes, or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims."

Hello. I'm trying to learn a bit more about the blockchain ecosystem. 
In reading a few arch (like FAB-37 docs), I could not understand the pre-reqs a client should keep in mind before venturing into development / deployment of the fabric. And how it would integrate / communicate with smart contracts.
Is there some information available that explains what the peer needs to have in order to carry out various transactions for endorsing, commits, etc.?
I also see a mention of HSM for crypto. I also see ACL, CC2CC. But where can I find more details on security.
Or perhaps I'm looking at it the wrong way. The framework provides the means, it's really left to the org to implement the protocols as needed for their use case.
<@U3MBTR5KK> the Fabric has smart contract capabilities integrated - we call it 'chaincode'

the end-to-end documentation is still a WIP but you can probably get a sense for how one would interact with the Fabric by reading the Fabric SDK specification <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1R5RtIBMW9fZpli37E5Li5_Q9ve3BnQ4q3gWmGZj6Sv4/edit>
we keep all of the design docs here in the wiki as well <https://wiki.hyperledger.org/community/fabric-design-docs>

text: <@U38GR81GW|wrabadi> pinned a message to this channel.
Hello friends, can someone guide me on experiences with using a standalone identity provider instead of member-srvc.

<@U3XNURGCC> see the boostrap.feature and the drill into bootstrap_impl.py which flows through to bootstrap_util.py.  These are under the bddtests folder.  The default behave test uses a mechanism that incorporates creating your own x509 artifacts.
<@U3XNURGCC> by running the '>behave -k features/bootstrap.feature' you will have created all of the x509 artifacts under the volues/peer/... folders
<@U0PKMSYKG> thanks for the tip. trying it out now.
hi all, has anyone tried service discovery of dockers in a fabric setup - using a tool like consul?
if yes, what are the configurations that go into the `grpc`.
Has any body implemented pbft successfully on 4 different vm each on different cloud ?
can anyone redirect me to a documentation for Fabric which describes in detail how data is committed to the underlying database on each peer after a consensus is reached?
